story: NewsopinionWell done, Matt Hancock. You could not have cocked things up any moreyoud triedMore than one political career will be killed off by the pandemic, but that of the Health Secretary is closest to , freshly-dug gravesShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  JUN Newsopinion" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFor me, Matt Hancock announced to the nation yesterday, what matters is what works. His portentous, I-am-serious-me statement did not add so I can f*** it right up at the end, but it might as well have done.As Britain emerges from lockdown and , excess deaths, mostly due to the virus getting a bit tired rather than any brilliance on the governmentaposs part, blame is being bundled up in preparation for the Prime Ministerial reshuffle which will send it as far away as possible.One of the recipients will be the Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, whose response to a health pandemic has been to destroy the health and social care of as many people as possible, with a level of incompetence that is close to brilliantly awful.  At the start of April, Apple and Google joined forces to use smartphones to trace coronavirus outbreaks. Within days, journalists were briefed the NHS was developing its own version, available in weeks, to ease lockdown. The fact UK local authorities had public health officials trained in tracing disease outbreaks was barely mentioned.On April , Halfcocked announced: Today I wanted to outline the next step: a new NHS app for contact tracing [...] We’re already testing this app and as we do this we’re working closely with the world’s leading tech companies and renowned experts in digital safety and ethics.”On April  it was reported Apple had refused to downgrade its privacy rules, which the NHS app needed to work.On April  Halfcocked said the app was crucial and would be rolled out in a matter of weeks. On April , a parliamentary committee was told it would be ready in a fortnight, and the Apple Google version of a tracing app had been rejected as it would slow us down quite considerably. All tracing apps rely on bluetooth connections between phones, but they store data dferently. The UK insisted all contacts be uploaded automatically onto a central server, regardless of health status Apple and Google kept data offline on your phone, pinging warnings out to anonymised contacts only when an infection is confirmed. The international version would also be built into operating systems, putting it on billions of phones worldwide, rather than relying on people specically downloading it.Most of the world went with Apple and Google. In Europe, only Britain and France insisted on a homebrew. On April  Germany switched sides, announcing a national app would not run on iPhones unless the screens were unlocked and the app running.Halfcocked doubled down. By then contracts had been signed with a bunch of private companies to provide software engineers, data processing centres, and servers.On April , the government announced the app would be tested on the Isle of Wight. Hancock said it was islandersapos civic duty to download it. On May , the Health Service Journal reported claims it was not fit for inclusion in the NHSapos own app library, had not passed basic cybersecurity tests, and was “wobbly”. On May , barristers warned the government might be sued over privacy and data protection concerns, and cyber experts said it was open to trolling, and foreign spies shutting down entire cities with fake reports.The same day, Halfcocked said the app was a very, very positive step in terms of us all being able to get some of our liberty back”. It was reported, again, the app wouldnapost work on locked iPhones, and would make safe international travel impossible.On May , Isle of Wight users said it didnapost work on older iPhones, Australia announced it was going with Apple Google after its own app didnapost work well enough, and the government had given £.m to a Swiss firm to seeit could somehow blend the Apple technology with the British app.On May , it was revealed the NHSX app was being rebuilt. On May , the government said it was not. Experts, again, said they were worried the NHSX version relied on self-reporting, rather than a diagnostic test, leaving it open to trolls and abuse. On May , NHSX finally admitted the app didnapost work on older phones. On May , MPs heard the UK app would not work with the Irish version, so any cross-border infections in Northern Ireland would not be picked up.Yet on May , Halfcocked boasted to Parliament: We now have the elements we need to roll out our national Test  Trace service – the testing capacity, the tracing capability and the technology. It was announced, again, the app would be rolled out within weeks.  Apple and Google launched their app - the one that would slow us down - on May . Four days later, the Department of Health gave £million to local authorities so their public health experts could help with tracking and tracing.On May , the Mirror revealed the PMaposs chief adviser had broken lockdown rules while infectious. On May , we revealed heaposd done so twice. On May , Halfcocked set , human contract tracers to work before the app was ready, and said he was getting people used to the idea. A DoH announcement said it would be complemented by the app in coming weeks. On May , he bent maths to announce heaposd hit his target of , tests a day early.  Halfcocked did not mention the app in his opening statements at the daily coronavirus briefings on June , ,  or . On June  the UK Statistics Authority said his figures were far from complete and comprehensible. On June , he thanked Serco - one of the firms involved in the app - for its assistance in the tracing programme.This week, Parliament was told the app would not be ready until winter and, besides, it was not a priority. Yesterday,  weeks after sanity required it, the government abandoned it.Turns out, the NHSX app didnapost work on older phones. It drained battery le. There were privacy concerns. Oh, and it and only traced % of an infected personaposs contacts, so you might as well have thrown all those millions into the English Channel along with a few thousand extra dead bodies.It was going to be available in weeks,  weeks ago. It was being tested, before the code was even written. The much-slower Apple Google app was produced quicker, works better, and was probably cheaper. Country after country hit problems and changed direction, but Halfcocked ploughed on. Sources, leaks, experts, and barristers all pointed out issues, but millions were spaffed up a wall trying to get the Swiss to do something weaposd have been sued for. Most of the developed world now has a phone app but we do not, and Halfcocked refuses to tell us when we might.Itaposs now obvious the app would never have achieved the critical mass of % that Parliament was told it needed, and that contact tracing was botched, then rushed out early to save embarrassment over ious Cummings and goings. Easing lockdown is now even less safe than it was, which was not very.And it seems as though Halfcocked is the worst kind of gambler - stupid. He fell for the apossunk cost fallacyapos - the idea that,you spend enough cash, a payout is guaranteed. story: NewsWhat £bn school catch-up fund will pay for - and why nurseries are furiousThe government is pouring £bn into Englands schools to fund tuition amid coronavirus. But the money will only arrive in September and there are concerns over how far itll goShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsIs Boris Johnson the teachers pet - or on the naughty step  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The government has promised a cool £billion for schools to help children left behind by coronavirus.The growing crisis in education has seen millions of kids unable to attend classes since the unprecedented Covid- lockdown in March. A report by University College London found two million children have done less than an hour a day of schoolwork during the lockdown. So today, Education Secretary Gavin Williamson announced a £billion package for tuition. But critics say it doesnapost do everything it needs to and there could be holes in the system. So what exactly will it pay for and how will it help your child  Hereaposs what you need to know. The £billion package is in two parts.The first is a £m fund to be shared across state primary and secondary schools over the   academic year to help all children catch up. Head teachers will decide how the money is spent, but the government expects this to be spent on small group tuition for whoever needs it.This is a universal offer - itaposs not just for the most disadvantaged pupils.The second part is a £m National Tutoring Programme to increase access to high-quality tuition for the most disadvantaged young people over the   academic year.Are nurseries and colleges included   No, itaposs just for schools. Nurseries and colleges were included in an erroneous early version of a press release that was sent to journalists before being rescinded. Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said he wants to support nurseries separately through the Hungry Little Minds scheme, and then move to further education too. He promised extra support but gave no firm commitment. Purnima Tanuku, Chief Executive of National Day Nurseries Association, said: “Yet again the Government fails the early years sector and very young children who are most in need of support. “Many nurseries have reopened to very few children and their businesses are just not financially viable. Neil Leitch, chief executive of the Early Years Alliance added: It beggars belief that the early years sector has been excluded from this aposcatch-upapos package. Childcare settings across the country are working hard to provide the best possible support to those children who have missed several weeks of important early education. Why is it then, that once again, schools get much-needed financial support and early years providers donapost  Will the cash be paid over the summer   No.When Boris Johnson announced the fund he said it would be a massive catch-up programme for summer and beyond.But Schools Minister Nick Gibb admitted the fund will only start to be distributed from September. Speaking on BBC Breakfast, he said: Schools will know itaposs coming and they will be able to budget on that basisthey want to do things before September. But the money will start being distributed to schools from the next academic year, September. How far will the money go   The Department for Education said it came on top of a £m fund for laptops for kids in need. Sir Peter Lampl, founder and chairman of the Sutton Trust, described it as a large sum in a government press release. But Luke Sibieta, a research fellow at the IFS think tank, said the money was worth just £ per child - a % increase in . And he said the rise would still leave spending per pupil more than % below its level in  in real terms.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHe is Everton’s “biggest fan” while she is “ per cent” Liverpool. But when footie-mad Cahill Corner and Kellise Campbell teamed up for a chat, the two rivals soon realised they had plenty of common goals. Talking before Sunday’s Merseyside derby on a Zoom call arranged as part of the Mirror’s Britain Connects project and the Great Get Together, the youngsters opened up to each other about their lives in lockdown. And the subjects ranged from missing family to hopes for the match and their careers. In her all-red bedroom – full of posters, pendants and scarves – Kellise, , introduces herself by saying: “I’m the world’s biggest Liverpool fan,  per cent.” And in his Everton-themed room a short walk away – with its blue and white bed, shirts and mascots – Cahill, nine, says “Hi” and declares he is “the world’s biggest Everton fan”. But for an hour, they put dferences aside to join Britain Connects and mark the weekend of the Great Get Together, in memory of late Labour MP Jo Cox – who would be  on Monday. The Mirror is bringing thousands with opposing views together while the Great Get Together hosts virtual events, from plant swaps to open mic nights. After months unable to watch or play games, Cahill and Kellise agree this derby is extra-special. In their football-mad city, where the rival stadiums are less than a mile apart, an Everton v Liverpool fixture is always a big deal.  Goodison Park and Anfield are only a short drive from where Cahill and Kellise are talking – and they have very dferent ideas on the result. Kellise, who lives with her mum and three siblings near Toxteth, says: “I’m excited for football to start – I’m excited about the derby.” Cahill, who lives with his parents and three siblings, says: “I reckon we’re gonna win -. It’s about time we won a derby.” Kellise laughs and shoots back: “I think it’s about time you won a derby too.” After a chat about favourite players – they are both fans of each other’s big names and, of course, local lad Steven Gerrard – they talk of their own efforts to stay match-fit in lockdown. As they trade training tips, it is clear they have missed talking to other kids. And they soon open up on how tough times have been. “ Coronavirus has ruined everything,” shrugs Kellise. “It’s like the whole world’s gone on pause.”  “School stopping, football stopping,” adds Cahill, sadly. “You have to be home-schooled and there’s no one there to play with. I’ve been missing football, I’ve been missing school and I’ve been missing tournaments – winning trophies, stuff like that. I’ve been missing watching Everton live, going to Goodison Park.” Kellise says: “I miss going to the match. I miss singing You’ll Never Walk Alone. Sometimes I put it on in my room and shut the door.” Cahill says: “The worst time was May and April. That’s when it got serious. We couldn’t go to my nan’s or family members’.” Kellise agrees, saying: “It’s hard not being able to see family. The only way is Facetime and Zoom. You can’t go to their house, give them a hug and say ‘hi’.” Kellise goes to secondary soon and without the end of Year  to enjoy, she is a bit unsure about what comes next.  She says: “I miss my SATS – I was quite excited to do SATS. It’s sad. I start secondary in September but I’m nervous because I don’t know what it’s like and I won’t have seen my friends in months.” More chat reveals how resourceful the sports-mad pair have been. As well as daily runs, boxercise sessions and footie drills, they have cycled and worked out whenever they can – with family members and YouTube trainer Joe Wicks. When Cahill reveals his dad built him a footie pitch in the back garden, all Kellise can say is, “Wow”. Cahill, who is in the Everton junior team, says: “I wanna be a footballer butI don’t make it I’ll probably be a fireman or a paramedic. But I might an electrician or a gas person like my dad.”  Turning pro is also a goal for Kellise, who trains with a local team. She is partly inspired by England’s Lionesses. And as they chat, these two seem happy to spur each other on. “One day, you might play or I might play by working hard,” smiles Cahill. “Hopefully, boys and girls might be able to play with each other in a few years. “You can’t say boys are better than girls because they’ve done the exact same. Girls can do the same as boys, play football, do whatever they want.”

story: NewsCalls for CPS lawyer to be sacked after sharing concerning Britain First postKim Kendall, who has argued serious cases for the Crown Prosecution Service across Lincolnshire, has been criticised after the Britain First post appeared on her Facebook pageShareCommentsByMark Naylor:,  JUN News" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A top Crown Prosecution Service lawyer is under investigation after a post from far right group Britain First was posted on her Facebook page.Pressure is growing for Kim Kendall to be sacked after she was reported to her bosses by other lawyers. The Facebook post was a petition from Britain First calling for the iconic statue of Nelson Mandela in London to be torn down, accusing the Nobel Peace Prize winner and former president of South Africa of being a communist and a terrorist mass murderer. Grimsby Live says the post, which referred to murdered British soldier Lee Rigby, was shared on Ms Kendallaposs page last week.It read: I donapost remember the UK rioting after two black immigrants hacked to death a white British soldier in broad daylight... Just saying. Britain First is an extreme far-right group led by Paul Golding, who was recently found guilty of a terrorism offence, after refusing to give police access to his mobile phone when he ed from a political trip to Russia. It is claimed Ms Kendallaposs Facebook page was removed since the post was shared.  Richard Lunn, a solicitor and director at Haywood, Lunn and Allen in Grimsby, Lincolnshire, was one of several lawyers who complained to the CPS. He said: At the end of the day, whether you are defence, prosecution or judiciary, there is an element of trust which the public needs to have in knowing that we are acting impartially and objectively. If the public thinks that we are not, that trust will go and the system will fail.  CPS employees must follow strict guidelines which say they are required to be impartial, particularly when making decisions about whether cases should proceed to court or not. CPS rules under its Code of Conduct also says employees must not post statements on social media which contravenes their obligations. “Employees must not compromise their political neutrality,” it says.A second lawyer who saw the posts toldhe was extremely concerned by the material.Criminal lawyer Attiq Malik said: As a campaigning lawyer against racism it is extremely concerning to learn that there are those in our profession who have Britain First posts appearing on their Facebook page.” A CPS spokesperson said: Impartiality and fairness are central CPS values and these are underpinned by a clear code of conduct. Any allegations of inappropriate behaviour are taken very seriously and investigated thoroughly. Mrs Kendall, who works at courts across Lincolnshire, typically deals with listed sentencing cases, overnight remand cases and making decisions about whether bail should be recommended or opposed for defendants.

Fans could have to walk through disinfectant mists and have their temperatures taken on the way in to venues. Thousands of shows have been cancelled or postponed since the start of lockdown in March, and the government has been warned that tens of thousands of jobs are on the line. Some of the best-known venues in the country say they are facing financial ruin. Lucy Noble, who chairs the National Arena Association - which represents  of the UK and Irelandaposs biggest concert venues, including Manchester Arena, Londonaposs O and Birminghamaposs Utilita Arena - told : We are at serious risk. And the chief executive of Londonaposs Royal Albert Hall said that temperature tests, health surveys and disinfectant mists are among the ideas heaposs asked the government to look at. Concertgoers could also be required to wear masks, and staff will have to wear PPE under plans being considered. Eventhe two metre social distancing rule is halved, venues would only be able to operate at % of their capacity - which would not be financially viable, Ms Noble said. But bosses are optimistic shows can be back soon - although music fans will need to get used to wearing masks, she added. Craig Hassall, chief executive at the Royal Albert Hall, toldthat there could be lessons learned from South Korea, where theatres were able to operate during the pandemic. He said: We’ve asked the government to look at how venues in other countries have been operating, and the checks and balances they have put in place instead of blanket social distancing guidelines. The test case in Seoul – where a Phantom of the Opera production has continued running – has seen audience members walking through a light mist of disinfectant, having their temperature taken, and filling in a questionnaire about their symptoms and recent places they’ve visited. If we’re to find a solution, it is going to be a combination of numerous measures, from increased access points to hand sanitisers, Perspex screens and PPE for staff.  He said current social distancing rules will not work, stating: We’ve done some modelling using social distancing rules and our capacity would be reduced to around % with two-metre distancing, and around % with one-metre. In order for us to break even, and therefore be sustainable as a charity, we typically need a capacity of around %. The National Arenas Association said the lockdown has been catastrophic for venues and staff. On an average event night, it says member venues employ , people - of which upwards of % are casual or contract staff. Ms Noble toldthat eventhe government slashes its social distancing rules to one metre, it will not be enough. This is not financially viable for arenas, she said.  Even with one metre social distancing we’d be looking at a % capacity which is not workable for most of our shows which are large scale touring rock and pop. We are looking at what activity we are able to undertake in the coming months, but it won’t be live performances, these do not work financially on a two metre social distancing model. She added that although the backlog of cancelled tours could mean venues are open more nights next year, that is little help right now. Ms Noble said: We do believe that  could be busy across all the arenas because many tours are being postponed, but this doesn’t help our situation now where there is absolutely no income to our venues.  We are at serious risk.  Several venues have been forced to launch appeals to help them through the crisis. Among these is Alexandra Palace in North London, where bosses are facing up to a huge defecit. Askedit would be possible to hold events with customers staying two metres apart, a spokesman said it could happen - but itaposs extremely unlikely. He told : Anything is possiblewe are permitted. Once decisions are made then promoters, venues and artists etc will need to understand the new costing model but this is unlikely to work for anyone. Ticket prices would need to be higher and people attend concerts often for the atmosphere so itaposs understanding whether there is an appetite with both these in place. But he added: We are facing a £million gap in our budget for this year, and are estimating a £.million  gap for next year.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTwo sisters twirl strings of fairy lights as they listen to music and dance in a country park, hours before being stabbed to death by a killer who may have been watching. The grieving family of Nicole Smallman, , and Bibaa Henry, , spoke of the “devastating impact” of their loss as detectives continue to hunt the murderer. They were repeatedly stabbed by a stranger who stalked them in a city park in the early hours of Saturday June  while they were dancing to music. The killer sustained a serious injury as the sisters fought for their lives and left a trail of blood. In a statement, the parents of the two sisters said: “The greatest fear of any parent is that they will outlive their children. “What makes our situation unique is that two adored sisters were murdered together on the same night. “The grief we feel is palpable, our beautul and talented daughters gone.” The fact the sisters were dancing to music with fairy lights meant their attacker could have stalked them from a distance without fear of being heard. Police have received more than  calls from the public following an appeal for information. The sisters were killed in Fryent Country Park, in Wembley, northwest London, after meeting friends there to celebrate Bibaa’s birthday.  Searches of the scene are continuing, but police have found the murder weapon. They also recovered their mobile phones from a pond in the park. Police said the pair were in “good spirits” and “taking selfie pictures, listening to music and dancing with fairy lights” until at least .am on June . Friends had left their celebration throughout the evening, with the sisters ending up alone in the park by around .am. Their last contact with friends and family was about .am, police said. The bodies of the two women were found next to each other shortly after pm on June .  The killer appears to have spent time trying hide his victims in a wooded area. The sisters’ mother is Wilhelmina Smallman, the Church of England’s first BAME female archdeacon. Bibaa, from Brent in north-west London, was an “exceptional” senior social worker and “a passionate advocate for safeguarding vulnerable children and families”. Her family said that before she qualied she would drive disabled children to their activities, “singing as they drove along”.  She loved her family, including her father, a former amateur boxing champion and building contracting company owner, and mother, who trained as a teacher and to become a priest. Nicole, from Harrow in north-west London, was the youngest of three sisters, described as someone who “saw beauty in everything” and had a “very calm and positive attitude towards most things in le”. Her family said she was “a strong advocate for humanitarian causes and saving our planet” as well as an “amazing photographer, actor and singer” with a “silky smooth” voice. “Friends and family all agree she was beautul both inside and out,” her family said. They added: “Bibaa and Nicole were sisters whose untimely deaths we will spend the rest of our lives trying to come to terms with. “The tributes for our girls keep flooding in it has been comforting, heartbreaking and at times overwhelming. Faith and prayer is keeping us going. I’m not sure how we’d get through this without it.”

story: NewsMadeleine McCann letter saga as Brit and German cops clash over proof shes deadGerman authorities and Scotland Yard are at loggerheads over whether a letter claiming Madeleine McCann is believed to be dead was ever delivered to her parentsShareByChris DyerTalia ShadwellReporter:,  JUN NewsMadeleines parents have never given up hope their daughter will be found alive " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA war of words has broken out between British and German police investigating the Madeleine McCann case. The forces are clashing over whether a letter informing Madeleineaposs parents her case was being treated as murder was passed on to the family. Madeleine has been missing for thirteen years since vanishing, aged three, from a holiday apartment in Portugal she had been staying in with family. Her body or any trace of her has ever been found. But German authorities have recently made a bombshell claim that they believe she is dead, as they unveiled a new key suspect in the case.  German prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters claimed his office informed Kate and Gerry McCann that authorities in the country believe their daughter is dead. But earlier this week the McCanns rubbished these claims, using their official website to issue a rare public statement insisted they have not received any correspondence from German investigators. Mr Wolters then insisted two letters were indeed sent via the Met Police in London, alleging British detectives then failed to pass them on. The first letter, dispatched at the end of May, confirmed that German police were treating the case as a murder, while the second was sent last week to update them on the investigation, Mr Wolters claimed.  But this afternoon Scotland Yard hit back, saying it did pass on a letter to the McCanns last week, but from the German federal police and not the prosecutorsapos office. A statement from the Met said the letter did not state there was evidence that Madeleine is dead. Scotland Yard added that the force has not received any such letter from the German prosecutor and is still treating the case as a missing person investigation. A spokesman for the Met said today: Following reports in the national press about the investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann, we are issuing this clarication. The Met received one letter from the Bundeskriminalamt[German Federal Criminal Police Office] on June , which was passed to the family.  The letter did not state that there was evidence or proof that Madeleine is dead - the Met continue to investigate Madeleineaposs disappearance as a missing person investigation. No letter has been received by the Met from the German prosecutor. The row has stemmed from an appeal for information made by German, British and Portuguese police at the start of this month for information about new prime suspect, Christian Brueckner. Scotland Yard maintained on June  there was no evidence to suggest Maddie - who would have turned  on May  - was in fact dead.  But on a German TV appeal just hours later, detectives said they were treating it as a murder inquiry. German prosecutors said they suspect the man they have named only as aposChristian Bapos abducted and murdered Madeleine.They also revealed they are investigating a -year-old child sex offender for murder, but have admitted they do not have enough evidence to charge anyone in the case. The -year-old German national Brueckner is a convicted paedophile, and has now been widely identied across the media as the key suspect. He is currently in prison serving time for drug dealing, and could be freed next monthhis conviction over a  rape of an elderly American woman is overturned. He has refused to speak to detectives investigating the Maddie case so far. Brueckner has racked up  convictions across Europe, including for sex offences against children, drug offences, theft and forgery.  He is serving a -month prison sentence for drug dealing and could be freed by July the European Court of Justice overturns his conviction for the rape of the -year-old victim. The woman was attacked in September  in her flat in Praia da Luz, and Brueckner lived about half a mile from her home at the time. Maddie vanished from the same resort about  months later. Brueckner was finally apprehended in  for the rape and jailed for seven years.He is appealing his conviction, claiming German police broke law by extraditing him from Portugal on a drugs charge but then putting him on trial for rape. Met Police detectives have said that the suspect was seen in the area around the resort of Praia da Luz, in the days and weeks before Maddie vanished on May , .

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPortuguese authorities knew Christian Brueckner was a paedophile before Madeleine McCann’s disappearance but still failed to quiz him, we can reveal. The German admitted he was a convicted child abuser after appearing in court in Portugal for theft in . Brueckner told the judge he served  months in prison for a sex attack on a youth in his homeland when he was a teen. The revelation that authorities knew of his conviction will pile further pressure on Portuguese officials. A senior Policia Judiciaria source said before that Brueckner was never quizzed because police did not know he was a sex offender. Detectives investigating Madeleine’s disappearance in Praia da Luz in May  questioned dozens of known sex offenders living in the area. But Brueckner, now , was never interviewed and ed to his native Germany months later. Brueckner was caught stealing fuel from HGVs in Portimao, Algarve, in April . In his first court appearance at the Judicial Court of Portimao, told the judge he was convicted of thefts and sexual offences at age . He molested a girl age six in Baia, in . It is unclearthe admission was passed to police by court officials.  Last week, a police source said of Brueckner’s conviction: “Back then, there was not the exchange of information between European police forces. The Policia Judiciaria didn’t know about it.” Brueckner’s suspected involvement in Madeleine’s abduction only came to light in , following a police appeal. An informant came forward claiming he confessed to him in a bar that he knew what had happened to her.  Last week a police source told Portuguese newspaper Expresso that “nearly all” Portuguese and foreign sex offenders were questioned. The paper said: “Although Brueckner arrived in Portugal in  after fleeing a child sex abuse conviction, he wasn’t on that list of predators. “That’s because back then, there was not the exchange of information between European police forces that takes place today. “That case of sexual abuse of a minor did not cross the German borders and that meant the PJ didn’t know about it.  “The German was known to police in Portugal, but for petty crimes he’d been convicted of which didn’t raise any alarm bells in May .” Earlier this month Policia Judiciaria deputy director Carlos Farinha tried to blame Scotland Yard for Brueckner slipping through the net. He claimed the German’s name was among hundreds passed on to the Met’s Operation Grange team in . Mr Farinha said: “If the suspicions about this man were so obvious, he would have been the subject of requests made by the British. “These requests were always authorised by Portugal, but those requests about him were never made. “If the PJ is being accused of giving Brueckner a lack of priority, the same could be said of the politan Police.”  Brueckner’s suspected involvement in Madeleine’s abduction only came to light in  following a police appeal. An informant came forward claiming the drter confessed to him in a bar that he knew what had happened to her. German prosecutors say they have evidence Madeleine, from Rothley, Leicestershire, is dead and are conducting a murder inquiry. It emerged today that police destroyed a van belonging to Brueckner which could have held vital clues about the case. He slept in the battered Bedford van at beaches on the Algarve and may have been using it when she vanished in May .  The German was in the van with jobless carpenter Tatschl when they were caught carrying out the  diesel thefts. He was given permission to get the vehicle back after his arrest but did not collect it within a mandatory ten-day period. However court records do not make it clearhe picked it up at a later date - and was using it when Madeleine disappeared. Expresso claimed it was actually seized by officers in November  after he failed to pay a fine for the fuel theft. The van was not swept for forensic evidence that German authorities are now desperately searching for.  Expresso said the blue Bedford CF was kept in a police compound in Portimao for  months before being scrapped. According to court documents seen by the newspaper it had the Portuguese registration plate AZ. Brueckner’s connection to the van has not previously been revealed by German or British police. They have only released details of two vehicles - a VW T Westfalia camper-van and a black Jaguar XJR . Brueckner also drove a mustard VW estate in Portugal and later owned a German-registered Tfin Alegro winnebago. The German paedophile lived in the Algarve from  until shortly after Madeleine disappeared from Praia da Luz.  He stayed in a dilapidated farmhouse close to the popular resort, where he often entertained his British girlfriend. But Brueckner disappeared in early , leaving the property a “rat-infested mess” according to one British neighbour.

title: queens message hope britains shops
story: NewsQueen joins fight for shops with message of hope for businesses in lockdownHer Majesty has issued a message to struggling retailers as high streets up and down the country reopen with hopes shoppers will help them survive Britains coronavirus lockdownShareCommentsByRussell MyersGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsThe Queen has issued a message of hope to battling retailers " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Queen has given shops a boost as they hope to bounce back from weeks of closure. As reopened retailers prepared for a post-lockdown sales surge, she said: “I wish all businesses every success.” The Royal Family today pitched in to help get Britain spending again as shops prepared for a bumper month of post-lockdown sales. After nearly three months of closure and uncertainty, retailers have reopened in an effort to ­kickstart the battered economy. The Queen told of her pride in firms that supported the NHS and ­the most vulnerable during the crisis, as they battled to stay afloat. And the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge today joined the family effort to encourage people to visit local businesses. It comes as shoppers are predicted to spend £billion this month and bring fresh hope to the high street. The Queen spoke amid a wave of support for the Mirror’s Shop for Britain campaign. In a message as patron of the British Chambers of Commerce, she said: “As many organisations around the country are reopening, I send my best wishes and support to business communities across the UK, Commonwealth and across the world. “At a time of great dficulty for many, it is heartwarming to see the civic response and generosity of so many businesses, small and large, to the challenges posed, whether supporting the health sector or vulnerable communities.  “It gives me great pride to see the contribution you and your members are making to help firms, champion trade and rebuild communities. I wish all ­businesses every success in their endeavours in the weeks and months ahead.” Prince William today lent his support to family-run Smiths the Bakers in King’s Lynn, Norfolk – not far from his Anmer Hall home where he, Kate and their children George, six, Charlotte, five and ­two-year-old Louis, have been staying during lockdown. The firm’s business mostly comes from wholesale, including to schools, which had closed. But it is now starting to see customers . William, , told Paul and Therese Brandon, who run the shop: “The important thing is that shops like yours can get the footfall back in again and the high street and town feel like it’s getting a little bit more back to normal.  I think everyone’s just been, you know, in a daze. They don’t quite know what to make of it all.” Scanning their products, he added: “I can’t come in here and not buy anything, so have you got any pain au chocolat at all  “My children will not talk to meI turn up without enough.” The prince bought four, costing a total of £.. Pulling out his contactless card, he declared: “I hope this works. Good, it’s still working, first time out in a while.” Not far away, Kate visited Fakenham Garden Centre – choosing plants and seeds for the couple’s children. The -year-old told owners Martin and Jennie Turner: “They love it. It’s such a great space for children and families to come to. “I’ve been food shopping but I have to say I haven’t been out a huge amount, but it’s good and so important, now as things start to ease, people know they can go out and particularly to places like this.” In another boost for Britain, banking trade body UK Finance backed our campaign. Its managing director of commercial finance, Stephen Pegge, said: “High streets play a vital role in local communities and will be central to the UK’s economic recovery. “We are proud to be supporting the Mirror’s Shop for Britain campaign.” UK Finance revealed banks provided , bounceback loans worth £.billion to retailers and wholesalers during lockdown. Many shops in England are thought to have held off reopening until today, despite getting the green light on Monday. Research showed shoppers can look forward to big discounts.  Brightpearl, an operations  for retailers, revealed almost three in  shop bosses questioned said the sales could dwarf those offered on Black Friday and Boxing Day. Official figures out today revealed a ­better-than-expected recovery in retail sales last month. Takings jumped nearly % between April and May, the Office for National Statistics showed. Intu, which owns Manchester’s ­Trafford Centre and Lakeside in Essex, said visitor numbers since Monday were up % on last week. George Brown, of investment bank Investec, predicted retail sales could rise another % in June. That would be an extra £billion, taking spending back above the £billion. He added: “Signicantly, this would take retail sales pretty much back to the levels seen in February.” Experts believe the online sales surge will slow as more shops reopen.  But Centre for Retail Research director Professor Joshua Bamfield warned the high street recovery would be slow. He said of today’s trading: “I think it will be reasonable, but it won’t be stupendous.” The Government has extended measures to prevent struggling high street stores being evicted during the summer until September.Best high street bargains as shops reopen The high street reopened this week and bargains abound. title: ten things brits plan continue
story: NewsTen things Brits plan to continue doing online as lockdown improves productivityA study of , adults commissioned by Virgin Media found many Brits think they are more productive working from home and plan to keep up some of the good habitsShareCommentsByAlice HughesJoseph WilkesReporter:,  JUN NewsThis study suggests working from home has major benefits " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - moneySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLockdown Brits have enjoyed living their lives online and plan to continue having digital social catch ups and exercise classes - because they believe it makes them MORE productive. A study of , adults discovered  per cent have used the internet more than ever while at home in recent months, with more than a fth believing this has changed their habits for the better. More than  per cent even said they have enjoyed their new digital lives, while a fth feel they are more productive thanks to the time they have gained from not having to travel to dferent places. Almost a third also said lockdown has proved they can be just as productive working from home, with  per cent planning to ask their employerthey can work from home in the future. A spokesman for Virgin Media, which commissioned the research, said: Itaposs great to see how well the nation has adjusted to living their lives online over the past few months. Brits have embraced digitally living and will maintain many of their new online habits even when lockdown is over. Whether itaposs catching up with friends and family via video calls, exercising along to online fitness instructors, to learning new languages over YouTube. With more people being just as productive while working from home, we expect to see more flexible working in the future, as workers have shown they can do their job as efficiently from home as all they need is a seamless internet connection. The poll also revealed a aposJoe Wicksapos effect with Brits spending on average two hours and  minutes exercising to online fitness classes. As a result, more than a quarter have worked out more than ever before, with  per cent planning to continue to follow internet-based exercises classes once lockdown is lted. Relationships have also improved as  per cent feel they have caught up with their relatives more often throughout lockdown. This has resulted in one in six feeling closer to their family and friends, while  per cent have also been better at keeping in touch and checking in on others. In the future,  per cent would like to carry on catching up with friends and family via video calls and group messages.  Virtual quizzes held over apps like Zoom or House Party have been the mainstay of lockdown and a fth would like to continue doing them in the future. Yoga classes, digital aposbirthday partiesapos and streaming live music and theatre performances are among other online activities people plan to keep doing. The results also revealed that Brits are honing their DIY skills by turning to online tutorials with almost a fth saying they will watch more how-to-guides in the future.  With extra time at home, people have also learned new skills via online videos or courses, including a new language , photographyand calligraphy . And  per cent found itaposs been easier to take up new hobbies from the comfort of their home rather than commuting somewhere. Likewise, of those who have followed online hairstyling or beauty videos,  per cent plan to continue to cut their families hair after lockdown to save money. And a tenth of those polled, via OnePoll, even plan to do their own nails in the future rather than visit a nail technician.

title: when first adopted were treated
story: NewsopinionWhen we first adopted it was dficult but now our boy is finally oursMum, Mirror columnist and author Roisin Pelan is battling breast cancer but she was determined to add to her family and adopted her son, BillShareCommentsByRoisin Pelan:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsopinionBaby Bill has joined Roisins family along with daughter, Ivy " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSo we’d done it! We’d brought our little dream boy home. I’m still in disbelief months later. It was bonkers for a while. When we’d first met our babe months earlier, his little smiling face melted my heart. Now that we had him home, it was still so hard to believe he was ours….a lot like it felt when we brought Ivy home from the hospital. Our poor boy must have been so confused to not have his foster family with him suddenly. He didn’t sleep well for a long time but throughout the day, he was - and still is the most smiling little ray of sunshine ever. Because we had constant social worker visits and calls and checks it felt like we were just babysitting for him for a long time and that was really, really hard. He’s a super clever little boy and when he started walking at only  months old, he was into everything. Boisterous, inquisitive and feisty. He bumped his forehead and we followed instructions from social workers to inform themhe ever has a bump….. it turned into an absolute nightmare for us. It was absolutely horric and even though we followed NHS guidelines for bumps , we were told one night thatwe didn’t bring him into AE, someone would come and collect him from our home. I was absolutely devastated to be treated this way and for them to remind usthat he was still classed as a ‘cared for’ child and we have to do whatever they ask. At one point, they even said they would escort us to the doctor. It was horrible. I  billion percent understand that they have to be soooo careful with adopted children because of all the horror stories that have happened in the past. But we had been subjected to the most thorough checks imaginable, character references, training, everything. The fact that we couldn’t be trusted with our own child was a massive blow. Obviously he was fine and the staff at the hospital thought it was ridiculous that we’d been forced to bring him in but that incident put us on absolute egg shells until the adoption was finalised.It was definitely a challenge but worth every single ounce of stress for those chubby little cheeks of his. He is the most snuggly little boy in the world, he loves a hug and it’s just the most glorious feeling in the world when he toddles over to me and hugs my legs. Ivy and him get on so well. I couldn’t have asked for it to be more perfect. It took Ivy a few weeks to adapt. It was a massive change for her and there were night terrors, tantrums - and of course jealousy. I felt terrible, we’d just turned her little world upside down. We honestly thought she wouldn’t cope. But she couldn’t help herself, she caved to his snuggles in no time and we were amazed how quickly she adapted.  We reminded her - and still do how special she is to us. We told her that she would always be our number one girl and Bill was our number one boy. We had one on one time every day so she still knew that we were there whenever she wanted. It helped so much and that’s something so important to consider when a new child comes into a family! Now we are free of scrutiny - don’t get me wrong, most of our social workers were incredible and we will keep in touch with them for a long long time. But now it just feels so good for him to be completely ours. For a while, I never dared to dream that this would be possible but like I always say, when you have hope, anything is possible.

Eleanor Williams, , of Barrow-in-Furness, faces seven counts of perverting the course of justice, which the court heard she denies. In a hearing at Preston Crown Court, prosecutor Jaime Hamilton QC, said the case involved a number of separate but connected incidents. The first incident was in October  in which Williams made a  allegation of rape and sexual assault against a male and then manufactured evidence to support the claim, he said. Three allegations of a similar nature were made against a second man which the Crown say was supported by evidence fabricated in text messages and social media posts by the defendant.  Williams faced two further counts in relation to an extensive allegation of trafficking and sexual exploitation by two men which the prosecution will say were wholly  and supported by fabricated messages, said Mr Hamilton. In a separate incident, she is alleged to have invented another account of sexual exploitation and trafficking.Judge Mark Brown, Honorary Recorder of Preston, said: They are simply allegations at this stage, which I anticipate that in due course Miss Williams will be denying. Louise Blackwell, QC, defending, said: Undoubtedly, the defendant denies it.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKeltie Byrne was a devoted lover of animals and wildle. As a marine biology student, the -year-old was desperate to get close to some of the most impressive beasts on the planet. Alongside her studies, Keltie also worked as a part-time trainer at Sealand in British Columbia in Canada. The popular attraction had first opened in  and was home to an orca called Haida, who had been captured the year before. He was a huge hit and aquarium bosses soon wanted a mate for him and caught Chimo, a killer whale who was a partial albino. Tragically, the orca died just two years later and Haida mourned her death, remaining alone for several years. But Sealand was not deterred and captured a second female orca, Nootka II, to be Haidaaposs mate. She died just nine months after arriving at Sealand. A third mate, Nootka III, then arrived at the aquarium, but Haida had absolutely no interest in her. By now, orcas were big business and when Dr Murray Newman, Sealandaposs founder, got a call from a man claiming to be feeding an injured killer whale calf by hand in the ocean, he went to investigate. The young orca, who they named Miracle, was suffering from a bullet wound and Sealand was granted permission to transport him for emergency care. Benefiting from the medical attention, Miracle soon became a popular attraction but had to be kept separated from Haida. But after a few years, tragedy struck when Shadow, Miracleaposs aquarium seal companion, died after drowning in the nets surrounding the pen they shared. Chillingly, Sealand er Larry McInerney told the documentary Who Killed Miracle  that Miracle had learned that by damaging the nets ers would come into her pen. It meant she could play with them but over the years she became more aggressive and this caused problems for the drivers, who struggled to keep up with maintenance on her pen. She too died a few years later and in the uproar that followed owners agreed to release Haida back into the wild. Sadly, he passed away just days before his release, although there was no evidence of foul play. Soon after, Sealand brought three new orcas to the aquarium - Tilikum, Nookta IV and Haida II. The three killer whales had been captured in Iceland after they were told to stop taking orcas from the water around Washington. But the relationship between the three orcas was far from harmonious. For almost a year, the three huge orcas were kept in a holding tank near Reykjavík, before they could be transported to Canada. Tilikum, who was now around  and a half feet long, could only swim slowly in circles or simply lie on the surface of the water. Gone were the sounds of the ocean that he had been used to for the first two years of his le, replaced with the low hum of the mechanical filtration that kept his tank clean. Tilikum, which means friend in Chinock, was finally moved to his new home on Sealand at the end of  - but this would be where his nightmare would begin. Tilikum, the youngest of the three was said to be bullied and chased by the two bigger and older females. Orca pods are dominated by females but there are reports that even after Haida II had become established as the leader, she still bullied Tilikum. This seemed to escalate at night so as soon as the final show of the day was over the three huge beasts of the deep were shoved into metal pods that were just  feet across and  feet deep. This would be their home for the next  hours before they were needed to perform again. One trainer, who worked at Sealand for two years in the late s, said the orcas would often emerge the following day with scratches and cuts from where they had rubbed against the side of their pods. Seven days a week, the orcas had to perform every hour, eight times a day and it seemed to be taking its toll. Both Nootka and Tilikum suffered from stomach ulcers and had to be given medication. And each of the whales had their own, distinct, personality. Tilikum, the youngest, was the most playful - he was described as youthful, energetic and eager to learn. Biologist Eric Walters, who was working at Sealand at the time, said: Tilikum was our favorite. He was the one we all really liked to work with. Nootka was unpredictable, possibly because of her health problems and had bitten her trainers and even a blind woman in the audience who had been invited to pat her. Sealand eventually recruited help from Bruce Stephens, a former SeaWorld head trainer, who was asked to make recommendations to improve practices at the aquarium. He is said to have given each trainer a handbook, which warnedyou fail to provide your animals with the excitement they need, you may be certain they will create the excitement themselves. The move was welcomed by biologist Eric but soon he realised it seemed to have made little dference. He said: They basically ran it like you would run McDonaldaposs. It just canapost be good for an animal that is so intelligent to do the same thing every day. It wasnapost long before Bruceaposs warnings began to take shape. The orcas would pounce on anythnig new that landed in the water. And they wouldnapost give it up freely, playing with items and refusing to hand them back to the trainers. By May , Eric had quit his job at Sealand and wrote a scathing letter to the Canadian Federation of Humane Societies, highlighting the safety concerns he had about the aquarium. He had a chilling final warning: I feel that sooner or later someone is going to get seriously hurt. Then on February , , just as the final killer whale show finished for the day, Keltie Byrne was tidying up when she slipped and fell half into the pool. She struggled to pull herself out but before she could haul herself back onto dry land, one of the whales had pulled her in. Keltie was a competitive swimmer but even so, she couldnapost escape the predators of the ocean. Head of animal training at Sealand at the time, Steve Huxter, said: They never had a plaything in the pool that was so interactive. They just got incredibly excited and stimulated. By now, the other trainers had realised something was seriously wrong and were frantically trying to attract the attention of the three orcas. They were throwing food into the water to seethey could distract them and bellowing recall commands. In a last ditch attempt to help Keltie, they three a le ring close enough for her to grab - but working together, the orcas kept her away from it. It was dark and chaotic and the trainers desperately trying to help from the pool side couldnapost determine which of the killer whales had hold of Keltie. Twice she managed to reach the surface and each time her horrying screams for help echoed around the pool. After  minutes of being Tilikum, Haida and Nooktaaposs play thing, Keltie bobbed to the surface for a final time. This time, she was silent - the student had drowned. Eyewitness Nadine Kallen said at the time: She went up and down three times. They almost got her once with the hook pole, but they couldn’t - the whales were moving so fast. An inquest found that the orcas had prevented Keltie from getting out of the pool and ruled her drowning death an accident. Little more than  months after Keltieaposs tragic death, Sealand closed its doors for good. SeaWorld bought all three of the orcas, with Tilikum and Nookta moving to Orlando, while Haida and her calf, Kyuquot, were shipping to San Antonio. But this would not be the only time Tilikum would kill. Eight years after Keltieaposs horrying death Daniel Dukes was found dead on the orcaaposs back while he was in his sleeping pool. The -year-old had visited SeaWorld earlier that day and managed to avoid security cameras to stay until after dark. He got into Tilikumaposs tank, naked, and when his body was found the following morning, he was covered in cuts and bruises. An inquest ruled he had drowned. Then, SeaWorld trainer, Dawn Brancheau was killed in front of thousands of spectators at the attraction in Orlando, Florida, by the male orca on February , . Dawn, who had achieved her goal of becoming a senior trainer at Seaworld at the time of her tragic death, had studied psychology and animal behaviours at university. When she graduated, she spent two years working with dolphins at an attraction in New Jersey before landing her job at Seaworld. Two years after Dawn started work at Seaworld, she became a killer whale trainer. She made sure she was as fit and healthy as possible so she could manage to rigours of swimming with the huge beasts from the deep. Dawn was one of the star trainers at Seaworld - she was key to the killer whale shows and her face was seen on billboards advertising the park. Chillingly, four years before her tragic death,  years ago today, Dawn had spoken out about the dangers of working with orcas. She had a special relationship with the huge killer whale, Tilikum, also known as Blackfish. He was one of the largest orcas at SeaWorld and he had been in captivity for more than  years. Those who worked with her said their bond was strong and based on love and trust. John Hargrove, who was a senior trainer at Seaworld at the time of Dawnaposs death, said: We’ll never know why Tilikum made that choice to grab Dawn and pull her into the pool. He had a great relationship with her, and she had a great relationship with him. I do believe that he loved her, and I know that she loved him. It was after one of the Dine With Shamu shows that Tilikum carried out his brutal act. Tourists could watch the action as they ate and Dawn had climbed out of the pool. She was lying with her face next to Tilikumaposs - the orca she had spent countless hours with and who had always treated her as a trusted companion. Suddenly, Dawn was dragged into the water. Initially it was claimed she had been pulled into the pool by her ponytail, but there were later suggestions Tilikum had grabbed her by her shoulder. What came next was truly gruesome. Tilikum didnapost just kill his trainer, the attack was prolonged and incredibly violent. Dawn, , was not only drowned, her left arm was torn from its socket, Dawn was scalped with her hair and skin found at the bottom of the pool. Horrically, her spinal cord was severed, while she also suffered from broken ribs, a broken jaw and a post-mortem revealed she died from both drowning and blunt force injury. Chillingly, the captive whale killed his trainer and then refused to release her body. For  minutes, he kept Dawnaposs broken body on the pool with him, despite attempts from the other trainers to distract him with nets and food. Eventually, they managed to get him into a smaller, medical pool, where he was easier to calm and he finally released the body of the trainer who had spent so much time with him. Following Dawnaposs death, Tilikum was sent to spend most of his days in a pool rarely seen by the public. There are reports that he would spend hours on end just lying on the surface of the water. Tilikum died at the Florida attraction in January . Six years after Dawnaposs death SeaWorld announced they would end their programme of breeding the orcas in captivity.

Deaths in the country also rose by ,, taking the official tally to ,, although the true figure is feared to be far higher. There is no widespread testing programme in the country with the true figure of cases thought to be as many as ten times higher. Second only to the United States in both cases and deaths, Brazil confirmed its first case of the novel coronavirus on February . The virus has spread relentlessly across the continent-sized country, eroding support for right-wing President Jair Bolsonaro and raising fears of economic collapse. Brazil had reported ,, confirmed cases on Friday, with and is likely to surpass , deaths on Saturday, although weekend reporting can be lower. Even so, the true extent of the outbreak far exceeds the official figures, according to many experts, who cite a lack of widespread testing. That number of  million is much less than the real number of people who have been infected, because there is under-reporting of a magnitude of five to  times, said Alexandre Naime Barbosa, a medical professor at the Sao Paulo State University.  The true number is probably at least  million and could even be as high as  million people.COVID-, the illness caused by the coronavirus, arrived in Brazil via wealthy tourists ing from Europe to major southeastern cities such as Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro and has spread deep into the interior, reaching % of Brazilapossmunicipalities, Health Ministry data showed.Bolsonaro, sometimes called the Tropical Trump, has been widely criticized for his handling of the crisis. The country still has had no permanent health minister after losing two since April, following clashes with the president.  Bolsonaro has shunned social distancing, calling it a job-killing measure more dangerous than the virus itself. He has also promoted two anti-malarial drugs as remedies, chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, despite little evidence they work. The far-right former army captainaposs handling of the crisis has prompted Brazilians to bang pots and pans regularly outside their apartments in protest, but it has not stopped him from wading into costly political battles with his own cabinet and the Supreme Court, stoking fears of instability.  Pressure from Bolsonaro and public fatigue after months of ineffective state and local isolation orders has led governors and mayors to begin lting restrictions on commerce and other economic activity. Public health experts have warned that loosening restrictions too soon threatens to accelerate contagion and drive up fatalities. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBritain is set to scorch in temperatures reaching up to C next week - the start of seven-day lockdown heatwave. Forecasters say temperatures are on the rise as we move through the weekend and into next week - with low pressure being replaced by sizzling European air moving in from the south. However, parts of the UK, especially the north west, could continue to see showers across the weekend before high temperatures next week. Met Office forecaster Alex Deakin said: Over the weekend we replace this humid air at the moment causing thunder, with another area of low pressure bringing in fresher conditions. There are signs into next week of drier, sunnier weather and perhaps warmer - specically in parts of the south. The north west is likely to remain more unsettled. We have low pressure nearby at the moment, winds are light so thunderstorms being creates are slow moving and thataposs why they are dropping a lot of rain. As we go over the next few days that is replaced by another area of low pressure - but that is coming in from the Atlantic and has very dferent characteristics. It will bring in fresher air and the winds will be stronger. After a mixture of conditions this weekend, Alex said next week could see a big change - specically for those in the south east.He added: A switch of wind direction means is pretty good news for the east coast. We switch to south westerly winds meaning eastern areas have an offshore wind so it turns much brighter and warmer. Beyond that, although low pressure is sticking nearby, it looks like it will hang out in the north west and higher pressure will move in. In the south and east high pressure means drier and sunnier weather - and it could warm up as well. European charts suggesting there is some really warm air nearby that could allow for some it to waft up across parts of the south. Some parts of the UK hit by a deluge of rain saw flooding after low pressure fronts brought stormy conditions. Hundreds of homes were flooded yesterday – some for a third time this year. Emergency services pumped water out of houses in Pentre, Wales, a village flooded twice when Storm Dennis hit in February. Yellow thunderstorm warnings were in place for London, southern England and parts of south Wales. Ryan Shelton posted footage of a submerged street in Ilkeston, Derbys, and said the flooding was “worse than ever”. The -year-old said it was “quite scary” how  minutes of rain left .m of floodwater.

title: lee wilkie dundee united scottish football lucky dundee fc wait
story: Making it work will no doubt be a massive task but Dundee United are one of Scottish football’s lucky ones as they ed to pre-season training this week.United and their  Premiership counterparts were able to get back on the pitch for the first time in three months with the Terrors conducting some socially-distanced sessions yesterday.Shaking off the cobwebs and getting back to it after a normal post-season break is hard enough but in coronavirus times it’s an altogether dferent task.Tangerines gaffer Robbie Neilson will still want to run the rule over his charges’ fitness levels as he plots how to tackle their first season at the top table in four years.Robbie will also be looking to see where he can strengthen in the transfer window with he and his staff working on the technical and tactical side of their game, too.The day-to-day challenges of the Covid- pandemic makes doing these things all the more dficult, however.There will be government, SFA and SPFL guidelines United will need to followwe are to continue to move towards the planned August  start date for the new top-flight campaign.Although that will be giving all at Tannadice a huge headache, just being able to get some sort of normality back to things will be a relief.It’s a massive step for the club and the first small one in getting back to proper football.They will have been stagnating for the past wee while and I can assure you the players will have been stirring in their houses raring to go.Robbie, too, will be champing at the bit to get his team how he wants it.You’d imagine small-sided matches between the squad and bounce games, when it’s safe to do, will go a long way in doing that.Jumping up to the Premiership, they’ll need to find that competitive edge again.It’s a big step for the club and one they’ve worked hard to achieve over the past couple of years.They won’t want anything to scupper their chance to shine on the big stage and will be leaving no stone unturned.I don’t think they are far away from being able to challenge for the top six with the players they have but a couple of quality additions would certainly go a long way to boosting morale.With , season ticket holders behind them, too, things are looking up again for United.Nobody, not least Dundee and their manager James McPake, will have wanted it to go this way.However, starting the Championship season in October is probably the best outcome for all that we could have hoped for.The costs for some of the smaller teams in the ision of starting earlier were simply too great.The issues and reservations were vast, perhaps not so much for the likes of Dundee and the now officially relegated Hearts, but definitely for part-time Alloa and Arbroath and newly-promoted Raith.In terms of adhering to all the coronavirus protocols it would have been a huge challenge but McPake and Co will still be left feeling slightly frustrated.They’ve already had three months out and now face another four before a ball is kicked in anger.He will be keen to get his side back in training to see where they’re at, what they need to do to strengthen and plan his assault on ashortened second season in the Dens Park title: former north east estate agent office could be transformed into new home
story: An empty estate agent office in a north-east town could be given a new future as a home.St Nicholas House on Banchory’s Station Road was the base for the Strutt and Parker firm until last summer.It used to be a school and is a B-listed property.Developer Grant Fraser has applied for permission for change of use for the schoolhouse building.A design station said the former office was “better suited” as a home due its design and history as an education facility.It said: “Although the building is currently categorised as a commercial property this application will demonstrate that the property is better suited as a residential dwelling given the buildings design and heritage as a school and schoolhouse.”The documents submitted as part of the planning application also said that residents in Banchory would back the scheme.It said: “It is likely that many local residents would support the proposed change of use from commercial to a residential dwelling on the grounds that the property is located in a mainly residential area and it will be sympathetically restored and well maintained as a family home.“It could also have a positive effect on the valuation of residential homes that are situated in close proximity because residential homes located next to commercial buildings are often devalued.“Conversion to a residential dwelling will signicantly reduce the number of visitors and the risks associated with those visitors parking on a busy main road.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: aberdeens greatest goal cup tie mckays first in the 1970 scottish cup final is our latest contender
story: It#s the conversation you could have with your pals all day # what is the best Dons goal you#ve seen Some of you will think it#s James Maddison#s unsaveably perfect free-kick against Rangers in , others Eoin Jess# run from halfway and incredible Ibrox howitzer in  or maybe Neil Simpson#s mazy run to score in the rout of Waterschei in .Over the coming weeks, we#ve decided to try to settle the argument once and for all by crowning Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal via a reader vote.As part of our Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal series, we are also running a competition for the best recreations. More details of the competition and the prizes on offer at the bottom of this page.To be clear, features we#ll run on the contenders for Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal, followed by a closing poll to determine the winner, won#t necessarily focus on goals of signicance which have secured silverware or qualication, like John Hewitt#s header in Gothenburg or Darren Mackie#s finish in Dnipro.What we are talking about is goals of technical brilliance, made either inidually or as a team, some of which could be meaningless in terms of competitions and silverware.Today#s contender was put forward by Evening Express reader Steve Buchanan, who said:#My nomination for best Dons goal is the second goal in the  Scottish Cup final against Celtic. A great team goal from one end to a goal in five touches.Derek McKay skins the full-back, what a pass toForrest, who shoots, goalkeeper parries and McKay scores.#Steve has summed up the goal perfectly, although it must be said the #full-back# McKay left in his wake during the break forward before playing in Forrest was Hoops legend Tommy Gemmell, while McKay#s finish # which put the Reds - up on the day # was also notable for being the th Scottish Cup goal scored by the Dandy Dons.More than , people packed into Hampden for the national trophy showpiece in  # one of the most famous days in Dons history. It is quite right for one of McKay#s goals, which completed a fairytale cup run for the late attacker, to be among the candidates for Aberdeen#s best ever goal.Speaking to the Evening Express in , McKay said: #Celtic kept pounding us, but we knew the cup was coming to Aberdeen when I made it - inside the last  minutes.#I back-heeled the ball over Tommy Gemmell’s head at the half-way line and raced away with it before passing to Jim Forrest, but his shot got blocked.#I was the first to reach the rebound and blasted the ball into the Celtic net.#Win a   Aberdeen kids kit and £ Smyths voucher in our Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal competition" title"#Win a   Aberdeen kids kit and £ Smyths voucher in our Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal competition# # Evening Express" src"https:www.eveningexpress fp sport football aberdeen-fc donsnews help-us-find-the-best-strike-ever-from-a-dandy-don embed # secretzPdlfpkOE" data-secret"zPdlfpkOE" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"We want youngsters to have a go at imitating our Aberdeen#s Greatest Goal contenders, with the club agreeing to give away a kids# home kit and kids# away kit for the two best efforts as chosen by our  of judges.
